ygData.subject: Re: Benchmarks for Artificial Embryogeny Systems
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, of course it s just speculation to contemplate why something never evolved, but that s a good point about the wheel having less utility without roads.

Jeff, of course it's just speculation to contemplate why something
never ev=
olved, but that's a good point about the wheel having less
utility without =
roads.  On the other hand, if the dung beetle can go
around molding pieces =
of dung, in principle a wheeled creature could
pave its own roads (i.e. fla=
tten some grassy areas) so it could more
easily drive on them later.  Also,=
 in some habitats, the ground is
relatively flat and probably could support=
 wheels anyway.  My guess is
that wheels would indeed be useful in some env=
ironments and "should
have" evolved they were indeed possible to encode.  T=
hat does not mean
they are better than legs in any way, but just as flying =
can get you
to some places more effectively than walking or climbing, and p=
lenty
of creatures get along fine without flight, I'd guess wheel-based
ani=
mals would get along fine too without walking.

My guess on why wheels neve=
r evolved is that a wheel has to be
separated from its axle so that it can =
spin unfettered.  It seems like
a hard problem to get blood/arteries/nutrie=
nts or any other resources
to such a separated piece.  Yet with all the wea=
r and tear (especially
on the outer membrane), there would have to be a way=
.  Perhaps it's
just too hard to encode such a decoupled transport system w=
ith DNA.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
=
>
> Hi Ken- 
> 
> This is a minor quibble on a side comment of yours, but I=
 think it
is fun to
> think about. I used to be amazed as well that evoluti=
on never
discovered the
> wheel. But then I realized that wheels are only g=
ood with pavement.
Since
> environments did not have pavement, it is no sur=
prise that evolution
did not
> discover the wheel. Only a complex process o=
f niche construction,
like we
> have done with our road system, allows the =
chicken/egg problem to be
> overcome such that it is worth it to both lay r=
oads and use wheels.
> 
> In natural uneven landscapes, legged creatures ar=
e much better than
wheeled
> creatures. Which is why we can't drive through=
 forests.
> 
> So I don't see this as a failure of evolution. In fact, we c=
an make good
> wheeled creatures but are just barely starting to be able to=
 make good
> legged creatures (e.g. Big dog). The legged creatures are bett=
er and
harder
> to make than the wheel.
> 
> What do you think?
> 
> That p=
oint aside, evolution did discover the wheel in some cases.
Such as
> dung =
beetles:
> 
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DI1RHmSm36aE
> 
> Some people=
 also have claimed that evolution has created the wheel
at the
> nano-scale=
. But I can't remember what the examples were.
> 
> None of this detracts f=
rom your main point, however, which I agree with.
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune=

> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> 
> jclune@...

roups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>

> > Subject: [neat] =
Re: Benchmarks for Artificial Embryogeny Systems
> > 
> > Derek, I also don=
't believe there has been a great deal of benchmark
> > comparison sine the=
 2003 paper, although Alexandre Devert cites a
> > few.  However, usually w=
hen people attempt benchmarks they do not
> > compare their results explici=
tly with others.
> > 
> > At the same time, as you know, I have changed my =
philosophy somewhat
> > since 2003 because I have realized that benchmark c=
omparisons can
> > lead to misunderstanding unless they are controlled very=
 carefully.
> > One of the problems is the "target-based evolution problem,=
" which
> > is one of the inspirations for novelty search.  In short, evolv=
ing
> > to an arbitrary target can lead to misleading intuitions about what=

> > is possible with a particular encoding because of deception.  Often
> =
> a "failed" encoding very well could represent the target if only it
> > h=
ad been led to it through an alternative path through the search
> > space.=

> > 
> > Also, another problem with benchmarks is that they may obfuscate
=
> > more fundamental advantages of particular approaches because they do
> =
> not focus on general capabilities.  (Although, of course, if you do
> > e=
nough of them, perhaps general capabilities start to be clearer.)
> > But t=
hat is why I advocated more focus on looking for biological-
> > like regul=
arities in the patterns output by particular encodings,
> > rather than loo=
king for a single particular pattern, or even a
> > single set of patterns.=
  Like I've said before, evolution never
> > produced a wheel but that hard=
ly means DNA is a bad encoding.
> > 
> > Of course benchmarks can play a ro=
le and I do think more comparisons
> > could be done, but we also have to b=
e cautious about their
> > misapplication.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > =

ing work that has
> > been

pers mentioned in the
> > other

imate goal is to create a

> >> flag!  I think it would be great =
to see such benchmarking of

e about the same as when
> > Ken
> >> wrote his paper: everyone is just try=
ing stuff with their own
> > system,
> >> without any regard to the other s=
ystems out there.

gh not as indepth as
> > his
> >> paper suggests) with my 2007 HyperNEAT pa=
per's results.  I built a
> >> program that let me look at the Hypercube pa=
tterns and we were
> > able to
> >> learn a lot about HyperNEAT by watching=
 how the patterns changed
> > over
> >> evolution, and were able to isolate=
 modules that contributed to
> > things
> >> like symmetry.  We have a fort=
hcoming journal publication about
> >> HyperNEAT in general that talks a bi=
t about this.
> >> 
> >> David

n vary from using only

genome? Is symmetry used, or is each point in the

for comparison."
